description: Manage software environment through modulefiles (Environment Modules/Lmod). The module command dynamically modifies the user's shell environment to enable access to different software packages, compilers, libraries, and tools without conflicts. Essential in HPC environments for managing multiple versions of software, compilers (GCC, Intel, NVIDIA HPC SDK), MPI implementations, and CUDA toolkits. Lmod is a Lua-based module system that extends Environment Modules with features like hierarchical modules and module spider search.

installation.notes: Lmod typically installed via package manager (apt install lmod, yum install Lmod) or compiled from source. Environment Modules available as 'environment-modules' package. Requires shell initialization in /etc/profile.d/ or user's shell rc file. Modulefiles stored in paths defined by MODULEPATH.

global_options.description: Output in terse machine-readable format, one module per line
Output in long format with additional details like version and modification date
List only default modules when used with avail
Enable verbose output for debugging module operations
Enable debug output showing internal module operations
Display help information for module command
Ignore module cache and rebuild from modulefiles (Lmod)
Show raw modulefile content without evaluation
Use regular expression matching for module names
Include hidden modules in output (modules starting with .)
Force operation even if it would break dependencies

subcommands.name: load
subcommands.description: Load a module or modules into the current environment. Sets up PATH, LD_LIBRARY_PATH, and other environment variables defined in the modulefile. Also known as 'add' in some installations.

options.description: Force load even if module conflicts with loaded modules
Apply a tag to the loaded module for later reference (Lmod)

subcommands.name: unload
subcommands.description: Unload a module from the current environment. Reverses the environment changes made when the module was loaded. Also known as 'rm' or 'remove' in some installations.

options.description: Force unload even if other modules depend on this module
Unload all modules matching the given name pattern

subcommands.name: list
subcommands.description: List all currently loaded modules in the environment. Shows module names and versions currently active in the shell session.

options.description: Output in terse format, one module per line
Output in long format with additional details

subcommands.name: avail
subcommands.description: List all available modules in MODULEPATH. Shows modules that can be loaded. Respects module hierarchy in Lmod.

options.description: Output in terse format, one module per line
Output in long format showing full paths and dates
Show all modules including hidden ones
Include hidden modules (starting with .) in listing

subcommands.name: show
subcommands.description: Display the contents of a modulefile, showing what environment changes will be made when the module is loaded. Also known as 'display' in some installations.

subcommands.name: swap
subcommands.description: Swap one module for another. Unloads the first module and loads the second. Commonly used to switch between compiler versions or MPI implementations. Also known as 'switch'.

options.description: Force swap even if it would break module dependencies

subcommands.name: purge
subcommands.description: Unload all loaded modules, returning to a clean environment. Use with caution as it removes all module-defined environment settings.

subcommands.name: spider
subcommands.description: Search for modules across the entire module tree, including those not currently visible due to hierarchy restrictions. Lmod-specific command that shows all modules regardless of loaded prerequisites.

options.description: Use regular expression matching for the pattern

subcommands.name: save
subcommands.description: Save the current module collection to a named collection for later restoration. Lmod-specific feature for managing module environments.

options.description: Overwrite existing collection with the same name

subcommands.name: restore
subcommands.description: Restore a previously saved module collection. Unloads current modules and loads the saved set. Lmod-specific feature.

subcommands.name: savelist
subcommands.description: List all saved module collections. Lmod-specific feature.

subcommands.name: describe
subcommands.description: Show a saved collection's contents without loading it. Lmod-specific feature.

subcommands.name: use
subcommands.description: Add a directory to MODULEPATH, making modules in that directory available for loading.

options.description: Append directory to MODULEPATH instead of prepending

subcommands.name: unuse
subcommands.description: Remove a directory from MODULEPATH, making its modules unavailable.

subcommands.name: whatis
subcommands.description: Display the description (whatis) text of a modulefile or search for modules matching a description.

subcommands.name: keyword
subcommands.description: Search for modules whose whatis text contains the given keyword.

subcommands.name: help
subcommands.description: Display help text defined in the modulefile.

subcommands.name: is-loaded
subcommands.description: Check if a module is currently loaded. Returns exit code 0 if loaded, non-zero otherwise. Useful in scripts.

subcommands.name: is-avail
subcommands.description: Check if a module is available for loading. Returns exit code 0 if available, non-zero otherwise.

subcommands.name: reset
subcommands.description: Reset modules to the system default state defined by LMOD_SYSTEM_DEFAULT_MODULES (Lmod) or initial configuration.

output_formats.default: Human-readable formatted output with columns for module names
output_formats.terse: Machine-readable format with one module per line (-t flag)
output_formats.long: Extended format showing version, modification date, and path (-l flag)
output_formats.json: JSON output available in newer Lmod versions

environment_variables.name: MODULEPATH
environment_variables.description: Colon-separated list of directories containing modulefiles. The module command searches these paths for available modules.
environment_variables.affects_command: Defines where module avail and module load search for modulefiles

environment_variables.name: LOADEDMODULES
environment_variables.description: Colon-separated list of currently loaded modules. Managed automatically by the module command.
environment_variables.affects_command: Tracks which modules are currently loaded in the environment

environment_variables.name: _LMFILES_
environment_variables.description: Colon-separated list of full paths to loaded modulefiles. Internal tracking variable.
environment_variables.affects_command: Maps loaded module names to their modulefile locations

environment_variables.name: MODULESHOME
environment_variables.description: Root directory of the module system installation.
environment_variables.affects_command: Locates module system scripts and configuration

environment_variables.name: LMOD_CMD
environment_variables.description: Path to the Lmod command executable.
environment_variables.affects_command: Specifies which Lmod binary to execute

environment_variables.name: LMOD_SYSTEM_DEFAULT_MODULES
environment_variables.description: Default modules to load when 'module reset' is called or on initial shell login.

environment_variables.name: LMOD_PACKAGE_PATH
environment_variables.description: Path to site-specific Lmod configuration Lua files.
environment_variables.affects_command: Allows site customization of Lmod behavior

environment_variables.name: LMOD_RC
environment_variables.description: Path to Lmod runtime configuration file.

environment_variables.name: LMOD_ADMIN_FILE
environment_variables.description: Path to file containing admin messages displayed when certain modules are loaded.
environment_variables.affects_command: Enables admin messages for deprecated or restricted modules

environment_variables.name: LMOD_COLORIZE
environment_variables.description: Enable or disable colored output in Lmod (yes/no/auto).

environment_variables.name: LMOD_PAGER
environment_variables.description: Pager program used for long output.
environment_variables.affects_command: Specifies how long output is displayed

environment_variables.name: LMOD_AUTO_SWAP
environment_variables.description: Enable automatic module swapping when loading incompatible modules (yes/no).
environment_variables.affects_command: Controls whether Lmod automatically swaps conflicting modules

environment_variables.name: LMOD_REDIRECT
environment_variables.affects_command: Controls whether module output goes to stderr

environment_variables.name: LMOD_CACHED_LOADS
environment_variables.description: Enable using cache for module loads (yes/no).

environment_variables.name: LMOD_IGNORE_CACHE
environment_variables.description: Ignore module cache and scan modulefiles directly.

environment_variables.name: LMOD_SHORT_TIME
environment_variables.description: Threshold in seconds for cache validity.
environment_variables.affects_command: Controls when to use cached module information

environment_variables.name: LMOD_EXTENDED_DEFAULT
environment_variables.description: Enable extended default matching (match partial version numbers).
environment_variables.affects_command: Allows loading modules with partial version specification

exit_codes.meaning: General error - module operation failed (e.g., module not found, load error)

common_usage_patterns.description: Load CUDA toolkit for GPU computing
Load CUDA and check what modules are loaded

common_usage_patterns.output_example:
The following have been reloaded with a version change:
  1) gcc/9.3.0 => gcc/11.2.0

common_usage_patterns.description: Search for all MPI implementations with spider

common_usage_patterns.output_example:
---------------------------------------------------------------------
/apps/modules/cuda/12.0.lua:
---------------------------------------------------------------------
help([[CUDA Toolkit 12.0 - GPU computing platform]])
whatis("CUDA Toolkit 12.0")
setenv("CUDA_HOME","/usr/local/cuda-12.0")
prepend_path("PATH","/usr/local/cuda-12.0/bin")
prepend_path("LD_LIBRARY_PATH","/usr/local/cuda-12.0/lib64")

common_usage_patterns.description: Load hierarchical module stack (compiler then MPI)
Save current module environment as a collection
common_usage_patterns.output_example: Saved current collection of modules to: "my-gpu-env"

common_usage_patterns.description: List available modules in terse format for scripting
Load NVIDIA HPC SDK with CUDA and MPI support
Check if a module is loaded (for scripts)
common_usage_patterns.command: module is-loaded cuda && echo 'CUDA loaded' || echo 'CUDA not loaded'

common_usage_patterns.description: Get detailed information about hidden prerequisites
Load Intel compiler and MKL for optimized math libraries
Search for modules by keyword in description
common_usage_patterns.output_example:
---------------------------------------------------------------------

The following modules match your search criteria: "gpu"
---------------------------------------------------------------------

  cuda/12.0: CUDA Toolkit for GPU computing
  nvhpc/23.7: NVIDIA HPC SDK with GPU compilers

error_messages.message: Lmod has detected the following error: The following module(s) are unknown: "cuda/99.0"
error_messages.meaning: The specified module version does not exist
error_messages.resolution: Use 'module avail cuda' to see available versions, or 'module spider cuda' to search all available versions

error_messages.message: Lmod has detected the following error: These module(s) or extension(s) exist but cannot be loaded as requested: "openmpi/4.1.4"
error_messages.meaning: Module exists but has unmet prerequisites (common in hierarchical module systems)
error_messages.resolution: Use 'module spider openmpi/4.1.4' to see required prerequisites (e.g., compiler module)

error_messages.message: Module ERROR: Tcl command execution failed: conflict cuda
error_messages.meaning: The module conflicts with another loaded module
error_messages.resolution: Unload the conflicting module first with 'module unload <conflicting_module>' or use 'module swap'

error_messages.message: Unable to locate a modulefile for 'cuda'
error_messages.meaning: No modulefile found for the specified module name
error_messages.resolution: Check module name spelling, verify MODULEPATH includes the correct directories, use 'module avail' to list available modules

error_messages.message: Lmod Warning: Did not find: cuda
error_messages.meaning: Module not found in current MODULEPATH
error_messages.resolution: Use 'module spider cuda' to search across all module trees, or check if additional module paths need to be added with 'module use'

error_messages.meaning: The environment is not properly configured for the module system
error_messages.resolution: Source the module initialization script (e.g., 'source /etc/profile.d/modules.sh' or 'source /etc/profile.d/lmod.sh')

error_messages.message: Lmod has detected the following error: A load of module "gcc/11.2.0" would change existing modules
error_messages.meaning: Loading this module would require unloading/reloading other modules
error_messages.resolution: Either purge modules first with 'module purge', or set LMOD_AUTO_SWAP=yes to allow automatic swapping

error_messages.message: The following dependent module(s) are not currently loaded: gcc
error_messages.meaning: The module requires a prerequisite module to be loaded first
error_messages.resolution: Load the prerequisite module first (e.g., 'module load gcc' then 'module load openmpi')

error_messages.message: Lmod has detected the following error: Cannot unload module "cuda/12.0", it is required by: nccl/2.18
error_messages.meaning: Another loaded module depends on this module
error_messages.resolution: Unload dependent modules first, or use '--force' flag to force unload (may break other modules)

error_messages.meaning: The specified saved module collection does not exist
error_messages.resolution: Use 'module savelist' to see available collections, or save current modules with 'module save my-collection'

error_messages.meaning: The module has been marked as deprecated by administrators
error_messages.resolution: Consider using a newer version. Check admin messages for recommended alternatives.

interoperability.notes: The 'ml' command is a convenient shortcut for common module operations in Lmod: 'ml' alone lists loaded modules, 'ml foo' loads foo, 'ml -foo' unloads foo. Module commands are typically sourced into the shell rather than executed as subprocesses. In Slurm job scripts, modules should be loaded after any Slurm directives. Module hierarchies are common in HPC where loading a compiler unlocks MPI modules built with that compiler. Spack package manager can generate modulefiles. NVIDIA HPC SDK (nvhpc) provides modulefiles for CUDA, nvcc, and GPU-optimized compilers.

permissions.read_operations: No special permissions required. Users can list and load any module in MODULEPATH.
permissions.write_operations: Creating modulefiles requires write access to MODULEPATH directories (typically admin-only). Saving collections writes to ~/.lmod.d/ (user-writable).
permissions.notes: Module system itself requires no elevated privileges. However, some modules may set up environments that access restricted resources. Site administrators control which modules are available and can use admin files to restrict or message about certain modules.

limitations: Environment changes only affect the current shell session; child processes inherit but cannot propagate back
Module conflicts must be manually resolved unless LMOD_AUTO_SWAP is enabled
Hierarchical modules require loading prerequisites in correct order
Module caches may become stale requiring 'module --ignore-cache' or cache rebuild
Different sites may have incompatible module naming conventions
Saved collections are user-specific and stored in home directory
Environment Modules (Tcl) and Lmod have slightly different syntax in modulefiles
Some modulefiles may have bugs or set incorrect paths
Module unload may not perfectly reverse all environment changes in complex cases

reads_from.description: Reads MODULEPATH, LOADEDMODULES, and other environment variables to determine available and loaded modules

writes_to.description: Modifies PATH, LD_LIBRARY_PATH, MANPATH, and software-specific variables (CUDA_HOME, MPI_HOME, etc.)

triggered_by.effect: Available modules list changes, may affect module resolution
LOADEDMODULES updated, environment variables modified, PATH/LD_LIBRARY_PATH changed
Future loads use new modulefile; requires cache refresh for immediate effect

consistent_with.shared_state: Slurm job scripts inherit loaded modules from submission environment unless explicitly loaded in script
Module environment propagates to srun commands within job
MPI environment variables set by MPI modules affect mpirun behavior
CUDA module sets CUDA_HOME and PATH needed for nvcc compilation
